thread.title: Investors Elbow Past Dealers to Grab Treasuries at U.S. Auctions
thread.title_full: Investors Elbow Past Dealers to Grab Treasuries at U.S. Auctions - Bloomberg Business

author: Daniel Kruger
title: Investors Elbow Past Dealers to Grab Treasuries at U.S. Auctions
text:
Investors are crowding out Wall Street's biggest bond dealers, making it easier for the Treasury Department to finance the federal government's debt.
The 22 primary dealers, ranging from Goldman Sachs Group Inc. to Cantor Fitzgerald LP, are winning smaller allotments of Treasuries at auctions as investor concern about Greece's ability to remain in the euro and China's stock-market plunge led investors to take a larger share of the debt.
Dealers won 35.7 percent of the $58 billion in three-, 10-and 30-year securities sold at the monthly auctions, in line with the 2015 average of 35.4 percent which is the lowest on record, according to Treasury data compiled by Bloomberg. The dealer portion topped 50 percent in 2012.
 ``It is supportive for the Treasury market and reflective of the fact that dealers are less willing to take risk in this market in general,'' said Ian Lyngen , a government bond strategist at CRT Capital Group LLC in Stamford, Connecticut.
 The bid-to-cover ratio, which gauges demand by comparing the amount bid with the amount offered, is 2.83 for the entire $1.115 trillion in notes and bonds sold this year, compared with 2.98 in 2014. Marketable Treasuries outstanding total $12.7 trillion.
Investor demand declined at Thursday's 30-year bond auction after Chinese stocks gained the most in six years, with dealers taking 40.8 percent of the $13 billion offering.
``The 30-year is a much more challenging benchmark to underwrite'' due to its greater interest-rate risk, Lyngen said.
The 30-year bonds sold at a yield of 3.084 percent, compared with a pre-auction forecast of 3.081 percent in a Bloomberg News survey of six of the primary dealers that are obligated bid at the sales.
The Treasury auctioned $21 billion of 10-year notes Wednesday at a yield of 2.225 percent and sold $24 billion of three-year notes July 7 at a yield of 0.932 percent.
